answer_html: This ODE causes a slope field where the slopes are horizontal for every \(x\) and \(t=0\).This is not the case for the Field D.Hence, ODE (b) and Field D cannot fit.
answer_latex:
This ODE causes a slope field where the slopes are horizontal for every
$x$ and $t=0$.This is not the case for the Field D.Hence, ODE (b) and
Field D cannot fit.
hints_html:
To read slope field graphs, one chooses a t and x value and goes to that point of the graph. The slope of the line that appears there is the value of dx/dt at those particular x and t values (for example, flat horizontal lines have slope 0 and so dx/dt=0 there).

Secondly, check, if the slope field is independent of \(x\) or \(t\). Therefore, restrict the slope field to vertical or horizontal lines (maybe using a ruler), and verify if the restrictions look equal in any of these two directions.

The ODE is independent of \(t\) (only depending on \(x\)), if the vertical restrictions look equal.

The ODE is independent of \(x\) (only depending on \(t\)), if the horizontal restrictions look equal.

Thirdly, check at which \(x\) (for \(t\)-independent slope fields) the slopes become horizontal. At these \(x\), the appropriate ODE has an equilibrium, is equal to zero.

Or, check at which \(t\) (for \(x\)-independent slope fields) the slopes become horizontal. At these \(t\), the appropriate ODE is equal to zero.

To read slope field graphs, one chooses a t and x value and goes to that
point of the graph. The slope of the line that appears there is the
value of dx/dt at those particular x and t values (for example, flat
horizontal lines have slope 0 and so dx/dt=0 there).

Secondly, check, if the slope field is independent of $x$ or $t$.
Therefore, restrict the slope field to vertical or horizontal lines
(maybe using a ruler), and verify if the restrictions look equal in any
of these two directions.

The ODE is independent of $t$ (only depending on $x$), if the vertical
restrictions look equal.

The ODE is independent of $x$ (only depending on $t$), if the horizontal
restrictions look equal.

Thirdly, check at which $x$ (for $t$-independent slope fields) the
slopes become horizontal. At these $x$, the appropriate ODE has an
equilibrium, is equal to zero.

Or, check at which $t$ (for $x$-independent slope fields) the slopes
become horizontal. At these $t$, the appropriate ODE is equal to zero.
hints_raw:
To read slope field graphs, one chooses a t and x value and goes to that point of the graph.  The slope of the line that appears there is the value of dx/dt at those particular x and t values (for example, flat horizontal lines have slope 0 and so dx/dt=0 there).
Secondly, check, if the slope field is independent of <math> x</math> or <math> t </math>.
Therefore, restrict the slope field to vertical or horizontal lines (maybe using a ruler), and verify if the restrictions look equal in any of these two directions.

The ODE is independent of <math> t </math> (only depending on <math> x </math>), if the vertical restrictions look equal.

The ODE is independent of <math> x </math> (only depending on <math> t </math>), if the horizontal restrictions look equal.
Thirdly, check at which <math> x </math> (for <math> t</math>-independent slope fields) the slopes become horizontal. At these <math> x</math>, the appropriate ODE has an equilibrium, is equal to zero.


Or, check at which <math> t </math> (for <math> x</math>-independent slope fields) the slopes become horizontal. At these <math> t</math>, the appropriate ODE is equal to zero.
question: B 01
sols_html:
Field A:

  • The ODE must be independent of \(t\), because restricted to every vertical line (restricted to any \(t\)), the slope field looks equal.

  • We have equilibriums at \(x = -1\) and \(x=1\), because the slopes get more and more horizontal, the closer they are at \(x=\pm 1\).

  • For \(x\in(-1,1)\) the slope is positive.

This fits exactly to the ODE \(\frac{dx}{dt} = 1-x^2\) (d).

Field B:

  • The ODE must be independent of \(t\), because restricted to every vertical line (restricted to any \(t\)), the slope field looks equal.

  • We have equilibriums at \(x = -1\) and \(x=1\), because the slopes get more and more horizontal, the closer they are at \(x=\pm 1\).

  • For \(x\in(-1,1)\) the slope is negative.

This fits exactly to the ODE \(\frac{dx}{dt} = x^2-1\) (c).

Field C:

  • The ODE must be independent of \(x\), because restricted to every horizontal line (restricted to any \(x\)), the slope field looks equal.

  • We have equilibriums at \(t = -1\) and \(t=1\), because the slopes get more and more horizontal, the closer they are at \(t=\pm 1\).

  • For \(t\in(-1,1)\) the slope is positive, for \(t<-1\) and \(t>1\) the slope is negative.

This fits exactly to the ODE \(\frac{dx}{dt} = 1 - t^2\) (a).

ODE (b) and Field D:

This ODE causes a slope field where the slopes are horizontal for every \(x\) and \(t=0\). This is not the case for the Field D. Hence, ODE (b) and Field D cannot fit.
sols_latex:
Field A:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The ODE must be independent of $t$, because restricted to every
  vertical line (restricted to any $t$), the slope field looks equal.
\item
  We have equilibriums at $x = -1$ and $x=1$, because the slopes get
  more and more horizontal, the closer they are at $x=\pm 1$.
\item
  For $x\in(-1,1)$ the slope is positive.
\end{itemize}

This fits exactly to the ODE $\frac{dx}{dt} = 1-x^2$ (d).

Field B:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The ODE must be independent of $t$, because restricted to every
  vertical line (restricted to any $t$), the slope field looks equal.
\item
  We have equilibriums at $x = -1$ and $x=1$, because the slopes get
  more and more horizontal, the closer they are at $x=\pm 1$.
\item
  For $x\in(-1,1)$ the slope is negative.
\end{itemize}

This fits exactly to the ODE $\frac{dx}{dt} = x^2-1$ (c).

Field C:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The ODE must be independent of $x$, because restricted to every
  horizontal line (restricted to any $x$), the slope field looks equal.
\item
  We have equilibriums at $t = -1$ and $t=1$, because the slopes get
  more and more horizontal, the closer they are at $t=\pm 1$.
\item
  For $t\in(-1,1)$ the slope is positive, for $t<-1$ and $t>1$ the slope
  is negative.
\end{itemize}

This fits exactly to the ODE $\frac{dx}{dt} = 1 - t^2$ (a).

ODE (b) and Field D:

This ODE causes a slope field where the slopes are horizontal for every
$x$ and $t=0$. This is not the case for the Field D. Hence, ODE (b) and
Field D cannot fit.
sols_raw:
Field A:
* The ODE must be independent of <math> t</math>, because restricted to every vertical line (restricted to any <math>t</math>), the slope field looks equal.
* We have equilibriums at <math>x = -1 </math> and <math> x=1 </math>, because the slopes get more and more horizontal, the closer they are at <math> x=\pm 1</math>. 
* For <math> x\in(-1,1)</math> the slope is positive.

This fits exactly to the ODE <math>\frac{dx}{dt} = 1-x^2</math> (d).


Field B:
* The ODE must be independent of <math> t</math>, because restricted to every vertical line (restricted to any <math>t</math>), the slope field looks equal.
* We have equilibriums at <math>x = -1 </math> and <math> x=1 </math>, because the slopes get more and more horizontal, the closer they are at <math> x=\pm 1</math>. 
* For <math> x\in(-1,1)</math> the slope is negative.

This fits exactly to the ODE <math>\frac{dx}{dt} = x^2-1</math> (c).



Field C:
* The ODE must be independent of <math> x</math>, because restricted to every horizontal line (restricted to any <math>x</math>), the slope field looks equal.
* We have equilibriums at <math>t = -1 </math> and <math> t=1 </math>, because the slopes get more and more horizontal, the closer they are at <math> t=\pm 1</math>. 
* For <math> t\in(-1,1)</math> the slope is positive, for <math> t<-1</math> and <math> t>1</math> the slope is negative.

This fits exactly to the ODE <math>\frac{dx}{dt} = 1 - t^2</math> (a).



ODE (b) and Field D:

This ODE causes a slope field where the slopes are horizontal for every <math> x </math> and <math> t=0</math>. This is not the case for the Field D. Hence, ODE (b) and Field D cannot fit.
statement_html:
For the following questions, refer to the slope fields in the figure below. Match the plots below with the differential equations by filling in the box with A, B, C, D, or NOT (for “None Of These”).

  • (a) The equation \(\frac{dx}{dt} = 1 - t^2\) matches the slope field ______.

  • (b) The equation \(\frac{dx}{dt} = t(t-1)(t+1)\) matches the slope field ______.

  • (c) The equation \(\frac{dx}{dt} = x^2 - 1\) matches the slope field ______.

  • (d) The equation \(\frac{dx}{dt} = 1 - x^2\) matches the slope field ______.
statement_latex:
For the following questions, refer to the slope fields in the figure
below. Match the plots below with the differential equations by filling
in the box with A, B, C, D, or NOT (for ``None Of These'').

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \textbf{(a)} The equation $\frac{dx}{dt} = 1 - t^2$ matches the slope
  field \_\_\_\_\_\_.
\item
  \textbf{(b)} The equation $\frac{dx}{dt} = t(t-1)(t+1)$ matches the
  slope field \_\_\_\_\_\_.
\item
  \textbf{(c)} The equation $\frac{dx}{dt} = x^2 - 1$ matches the slope
  field \_\_\_\_\_\_.
\item
  \textbf{(d)} The equation $\frac{dx}{dt} = 1 - x^2$ matches the slope
  field \_\_\_\_\_\_.
\end{itemize}
